page.title: 07Electricity Supply.
page.content: Every house in our area is supplied with electricity in the form of alternating current at 50 cycles per second and 240 Volts pressure. As our country is small it is convenient to link all the generating stations together by overhead power cables. This is known as the 'national grid'. This means that if any one station is shut down, the working stations can share the load. Only very rarely is there a voltage reduction or a black out. The power lines in our area carry electricity at 11000 Volts. Transformer substations reduce this to 240 Volts, more convenient for our use Modern wiring uses a ring main system fused at 30 Amperes. Any individual plug can take a maximum of l3 Amperes but may be fused at a much lower rating than this.
